myth: You should eat for two during pregnancy.
fact: Pregnant women only need about 300 extra calories per day in the second and third trimesters, not double the food.

myth: Morning sickness only happens in the morning.
fact: Nausea and vomiting can occur at any time of the day during pregnancy.

myth: Pregnant women should avoid all exercise.
fact: Moderate exercise is safe and beneficial during most pregnancies unless advised otherwise by a healthcare provider.

myth: Heartburn means the baby will have lots of hair.
fact: Heartburn is caused by hormonal changes and stomach pressure, not directly linked to a baby's hair growth.

myth: You cannot dye your hair while pregnant.
fact: Occasional hair dye use is generally considered safe, especially after the first trimester, but consult your doctor.

myth: You should avoid all seafood during pregnancy.
fact: Low-mercury fish like salmon and sardines are safe and provide important nutrients such as omega-3 fatty acids.

myth: Spicy foods can induce labor.
fact: There’s no scientific evidence that spicy foods trigger labor.

myth: Pregnant women should avoid flying.
fact: Flying is generally safe until the last month of pregnancy, though long flights may increase risk of blood clots.

myth: Carrying high or low predicts the baby’s gender.
fact: Belly shape depends on muscle tone, body type, and baby’s position—not gender.

myth: Pregnant women should avoid sleeping on their left side.
fact: Sleeping on the left side is actually recommended as it improves blood flow to the baby.

myth: Cravings reveal what nutrients the baby needs.
fact: Cravings are common but not reliable indicators of nutritional needs.

myth: You cannot drink coffee while pregnant.
fact: Moderate caffeine intake (under 200 mg per day) is considered safe during pregnancy.

myth: All herbal teas are safe in pregnancy.
fact: Some herbal teas may be unsafe; always check with a healthcare provider before consuming.

myth: You can’t have any sugar while pregnant.
fact: Moderation is key; occasional treats are fine as part of a balanced diet.

myth: Pregnant women must avoid baths.
fact: Warm baths are safe; only hot tubs and saunas should be avoided due to overheating risks.

myth: Stretch marks can always be prevented.
fact: Genetics and skin type play a big role; creams may help but cannot guarantee prevention.

myth: Pregnancy brain isn’t real.
fact: Hormonal changes and sleep disturbances can affect memory and focus during pregnancy.

myth: Heart rate can predict a baby’s gender.
fact: There’s no evidence linking fetal heart rate to gender.

myth: Pregnant women cannot get vaccinated.
fact: Some vaccines, like flu and Tdap, are recommended and protect both mother and baby.

myth: Lifting your arms above your head can harm the baby.
fact: There is no scientific basis for this belief; normal movement is safe.

myth: Pregnant women should avoid all dairy.
fact: Pasteurized dairy products are safe and provide calcium and protein.

myth: Cesarean delivery is the easier option.
fact: C-sections are major surgeries with risks; recovery can be longer compared to vaginal birth.

myth: You cannot have sex during pregnancy.
fact: Sex is safe for most pregnancies unless a doctor advises otherwise.

myth: Pregnant women should avoid vaccinations altogether.
fact: Vaccines like flu and whooping cough are safe and recommended to protect mother and baby.

myth: Labor always starts with water breaking.
fact: Only about 15% of women experience water breaking as the first sign of labor.

myth: Pregnant women should avoid pets.
fact: Pets are safe; only cat litter poses risk due to toxoplasmosis.

myth: Belly size shows baby’s health.
fact: Belly size varies by body type and doesn’t reliably indicate baby’s size or health.

myth: You must avoid cheese during pregnancy.
fact: Only unpasteurized soft cheeses should be avoided; pasteurized cheeses are safe.

myth: Pregnant women should avoid all medications.
fact: Some medications are safe; always consult a healthcare provider before taking any.

myth: Eating peanuts during pregnancy causes allergies.
fact: Eating peanuts in pregnancy does not increase allergy risk and may even reduce it.
